<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_add_page_size:
```c
static int metal_add_page_size(const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags)
{
	int index = _metal.num_page_sizes;
	unsigned long size = 1UL << shift;

	if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - overflow\n",
			  size);
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	}

	if (!path || shift <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - invalid args\n",
			  size);
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_shift = shift;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_size = size;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].mmap_flags = mmap_flags;
	strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
	_metal.num_page_sizes++;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "added page size %ld @%s\n", size, path);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

The index check (if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES)) prevents out-of-bounds access of the _metal.page_sizes array; the null check (if (!path || shift <= 0)) prevents a NULL path being used; the numeric assignments and increment of _metal.num_page_sizes are simple scalar operations not involving string handling. The other metal_log calls only format numeric values and do not risk string-buffer reads. No other uses of memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, or similar string.h functions appear in this function.
